statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description:
David Wesley scored 21 points and Baron Davis had 20 points, 11 assists and nine rebounds as the Charlotte
Hornets held off the Seattle SuperSonics 111-101 on Wednesday night.
article.headline: Sonics' rally runs out of gas in Charlotte

images.name: Wesley_David 012302 inline
images.caption: The Hornets' David Wesley runs into a brick wall named Vin Baker.

article.linkText: Hornets nearly blow 27-point lead vs. Sonics
article.story:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- David Wesley knew this victory wouldn't be as easy as the one Monday. Two days after recording a 43-point win at New York, the Charlotte Hornets jumped to a 27-point lead and had to hold off a late rally by the Seattle SuperSonics for a 111-101 win Wednesday night. "It's not that easy," said Wesley, who finished with 21 points. "That second half shows that if we relax even a little bit, we could be in trouble." Baron Davis added 20 points, 11 assists and nine rebounds, while Lee Nailon scored all 19 of his points in the first half as the Hornets won for the sixth time in nine games. Vin Baker and Gary Payton each scored 24 points and Rashard Lewis added 22 for the Sonics. The Hornets outscored the Sonics 41-18 in the second quarter with a barrage of fast-break baskets and 3-pointers. The Hornets hit 15 of 21 shots, including a 6-for-7 performance from 3-point range, to take a 71-46 halftime lead. It was the most points scored in a half this season by Charlotte, and just four shy of the franchise record. "After our effort in New York, we wanted to come out with the same intensity and focus," Davis said. "I'm a little disappointed in the way we finished the game, but hopefully we learned a lesson." Seattle coach Nate McMillan called two timeouts in a span of 16 seconds in the quarter, but the run continued. "The Hornets played the way basketball should be played," McMillan said. "We've got to play with consistency." The SuperSonics slowly fought back, cutting the deficit to 14 after three quarters. Reserve Shammond Williams scored nine straight points in the fourth, including a 3-pointer with 6:06 left to make it 94-90. But Elden Campbell hit three of four free throws and Wesley made a 3-pointer to put it out of reach. "At the end we picked it back up, started defending and made the key stops that sealed the game," Hornets coach Paul Silas said. McMillan took no solace from the Sonics' second-half spurt. "I want 48 minutes of basketball," he said. "Two quarters isn't enough to win. We played well in the second half, but the hill was too high and we ran out of gas." Charlotte shot 49 percent and went 9-for-18 on 3s. Seattle, which shot a team-record 66 percent in a win at Philadelphia on Monday, made 47 percent of its shots but was outrebounded 47-35. Game notes
The Vancouver therapist treating injured Hornets forward Jamal Mashburn is scheduled to return to Charlotte on Thursday. Mashburn has missed 32 games with an abdominal injury, but Silas is pleased with his progress. "He's smiling again," Silas said. ... Williams drove to Greenville, S.C., on Wednesday to visit his sick grandfather, who has a kidney disorder. "It was great to be near him," Williams said. ... Davis was 2-for-6 on 3-pointers, extending his streak of hitting at least one 3 to an NBA-leading 44 games. ... The game was the 41st for each team, marking the midway point of the season.
